sense.name: (cause to) go or extend across from one side to another
sense.commentary: Note: Movement is implied. Note: Metaphoric uses included.
sense.examples: Look both ways before you cross the road. We crossed the horses at the ford. We crossed Canada en route to Alaska. Cross the bridge and turn right at the first set of traffic lights. They crossed from Albania into Greece. We need to take the bridge that crosses the bay. Numerous fallen trees cross the stream. After living through World War II, I don't think worrying about the width of her hips ever crossed her mind! In the last 3 years particle physics has crossed a threshold in its basic understanding of the fundamental nature of neutrinos.

sense.name: (cause to) meet or intersect
sense.examples: A settlement grew up where two trade routes crossed. One day we will cross each other's path. We crossed each other in the hallway as I was leaving work. In 1996, fate crossed his path with Edward and he embarked upon that fruitful journey. Cross your t's and dot your i's.

sense.name: interfere or obstruct; make angry, frustrated, or annoyed
sense.examples: Don't cross me! I wouldn't cross her unless you want to make life difficult for yourself.

sense.name: fold or entwine body parts in a typical configuration
sense.examples: Megan crossed her arms and tapped her foot. Do not cross your legs for long periods of time. I'm still hoping and crossing my fingers.

sense.name: mix or breed things of different varieties or qualities
sense.examples: When you cross a horse with a donkey and get a mule. In one experiment, Mendel crossed a pea plant that bred true for axial flowers with a pea. What, I wondered, do you get when you cross a horse with a zebra? This movie crosses horror with humor.

sense.name: draw a cross in the air over something
sense.examples: Before he walked out, he crossed himself and said a short prayer. I cross my heart and hope to die if that isn't true!

sense.name: strike or remove from a list
sense.examples: If a choice violates the value, cross out the choice. She crossed tasks off her list as she did them.

sense.name: act outrageously; move from appropriate to inappropriate
sense.examples: Recent charges prove Jackson may have crossed the line from bizarre to criminal. That's it - now they've crossed the line!
